column5: $1 per day

column2: Share of population living in extreme poverty (Disposable household income, equivalized)
column5: $2.15 per day: International Poverty Line
column8: Extreme poverty is defined as living below the International Poverty Line of $2.15 per day. This data is adjusted for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.
column9: This data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices.

column2: Poverty: Share of population living on less than $3.65 a day (Disposable household income, equivalized)
column5: $3.65 per day: Lower-middle income poverty line

column9: This data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices.

column2: Total shortfall from a poverty line of $1 a day (Disposable household income, equivalized)
column5: $1 per day
column8: This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the incomes of all people in poverty up to $1 a day. This data is adjusted for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.
column9: This data is expressed in international-$ at 2017 prices. The cost of closing the poverty gap does not take into account costs and inefficiencies from making the necessary transfers.

column2: Total shortfall from extreme poverty (Disposable household income, equivalized)
column5: $2.15 per day: International Poverty Line
column8: This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the incomes of all people in extreme poverty up to the International Poverty Line of $2.15 a day. This data is adjusted for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.
column9: This data is expressed in international-$ at 2017 prices. The cost of closing the poverty gap does not take into account costs and inefficiencies from making the necessary transfers.

column2: Average shortfall from a poverty line of $1 a day (as a share of the poverty line) (Disposable household income, equivalized)
column5: $1 per day
column8: This is the average shortfall expressed as a share of the poverty line, sometimes called the 'income gap ratio'. It captures the depth of poverty in which those below $1 a day are living. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

column2: Poverty gap index at $1 a day (Disposable household income, equivalized)
column5: $1 per day
column8: The poverty gap index is a poverty measure that reflects both the prevalence and the depth of poverty. It is calculated as the share of population in poverty multiplied by the average shortfall from the poverty line (expressed as a % of the poverty line). Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.
column9: This data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices to account for inflation and differences in the cost of living between countries.

column2: Total shortfall from a poverty line of $1 a day (Disposable household income, per capita)
column5: $1 per day
column8: This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the incomes of all people in poverty up to $1 a day. This data is adjusted for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.
column9: This data is expressed in international-$ at 2017 prices. The cost of closing the poverty gap does not take into account costs and inefficiencies from making the necessary transfers.

column2: Total shortfall from a poverty line of $1 a day (Disposable household cash income, equivalized)
column5: $1 per day

Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits, but does not include in-kind benefits.
column9: This data is expressed in international-$ at 2017 prices. The cost of closing the poverty gap does not take into account costs and inefficiencies from making the necessary transfers.

column2: Share below $1 a day
column5:
% of population living in households with income below $1 a day.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.

column2: $1 a day - total shortfall
column5:
The total shortfall from a poverty line of $1 a day. This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the income of all people in poverty up to the poverty line. However this is not a measure of the actual cost of eliminating poverty, since it does not take into account the costs involved in making the necessary transfers nor any changes in behaviour they would bring about.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: $2.15 a day - total shortfall
column5:
The total shortfall from a poverty line of $2.15 a day. This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the income of all people in poverty up to the poverty line. However this is not a measure of the actual cost of eliminating poverty, since it does not take into account the costs involved in making the necessary transfers nor any changes in behaviour they would bring about.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.

column2: $1 a day - poverty gap index
column5:
The poverty gap index calculated at a poverty line of $1 a day. The poverty gap index is a measure that reflects both the depth and prevalence of poverty. It is defined as the mean shortfall of the total population from the poverty line counting the non-poor as having zero shortfall and expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. It is worth unpacking that definition a little. For those below the poverty line, the shortfall corresponds to the amount of money required in order to reach the poverty line. For those at or above the poverty line, the shortfall is counted as zero. The average shortfall is then calculated across the total population – both poor and non-poor – and then expressed as a share of the poverty line. Unlike the more commonly-used metric of the headcount ratio, the poverty gap index is thus sensitive not only to whether a person’s income falls below the poverty line or not, but also by how much – i.e. to the depth of poverty they experience.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

The average shortfall from a poverty line of of 50% of the median disposable household income (averaged across the population in poverty).

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: 60% of median DHI - average shortfall

column2: 40% of median DHI - income gap ratio
column5:
The average shortfall from a poverty line of of 40% of the median disposable household income (averaged across the population in poverty) expressed as a share of the poverty line. This metric is sometimes called the "income gap ratio". It captures the depth of poverty in which those below the poverty line are living.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: 40% of median DHI - poverty gap index
column5:
The poverty gap index calculated at a poverty line of 40% of the median disposable household income. The poverty gap index is a measure that reflects both the depth and prevalence of poverty. It is defined as the mean shortfall of the total population from the poverty line counting the non-poor as having zero shortfall and expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. It is worth unpacking that definition a little. For those below the poverty line, the shortfall corresponds to the amount of money required in order to reach the poverty line. For those at or above the poverty line, the shortfall is counted as zero. The average shortfall is then calculated across the total population – both poor and non-poor – and then expressed as a share of the poverty line. Unlike the more commonly-used metric of the headcount ratio, the poverty gap index is thus sensitive not only to whether a person’s income falls below the poverty line or not, but also by how much – i.e. to the depth of poverty they experience.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: $1 a day - total shortfall
column5:
The total shortfall from a poverty line of $1 a day. This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the income of all people in poverty up to the poverty line. However this is not a measure of the actual cost of eliminating poverty, since it does not take into account the costs involved in making the necessary transfers nor any changes in behaviour they would bring about.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

It is defined as the mean shortfall of the total population from the poverty line counting the non-poor as having zero shortfall and expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. It is worth unpacking that definition a little. For those below the poverty line, the shortfall corresponds to the amount of money required in order to reach the poverty line. For those at or above the poverty line, the shortfall is counted as zero. The average shortfall is then calculated across the total population – both poor and non-poor – and then expressed as a share of the poverty line. Unlike the more commonly-used metric of the headcount ratio, the poverty gap index is thus sensitive not only to whether a person’s income falls below the poverty line or not, but also by how much – i.e. to the depth of poverty they experience.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: 40% of median DHI - total shortfall
column5:
The total shortfall from a poverty line of 40% of the median disposable household income. This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the income of all people in poverty up to the poverty line. However this is not a measure of the actual cost of eliminating poverty, since it does not take into account the costs involved in making the necessary transfers nor any changes in behaviour they would bring about.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: 40% of median DHI - income gap ratio
column5:
The average shortfall from a poverty line of of 40% of the median disposable household income (averaged across the population in poverty) expressed as a share of the poverty line. This metric is sometimes called the "income gap ratio". It captures the depth of poverty in which those below the poverty line are living.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

column2: Share below $1 a day
column5:
% of population living in households with income below $1 a day.

This is disposable household cash income. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits, but does not include in-kind benefits.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.

column2: $1 a day - poverty gap index
column5:
The poverty gap index calculated at a poverty line of $1 a day. The poverty gap index is a measure that reflects both the depth and prevalence of poverty. It is defined as the mean shortfall of the total population from the poverty line counting the non-poor as having zero shortfall and expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. It is worth unpacking that definition a little. For those below the poverty line, the shortfall corresponds to the amount of money required in order to reach the poverty line. For those at or above the poverty line, the shortfall is counted as zero. The average shortfall is then calculated across the total population – both poor and non-poor – and then expressed as a share of the poverty line. Unlike the more commonly-used metric of the headcount ratio, the poverty gap index is thus sensitive not only to whether a person’s income falls below the poverty line or not, but also by how much – i.e. to the depth of poverty they experience.

This is disposable household cash income. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits, but does not include in-kind benefits.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

This metric is sometimes called the "income gap ratio". It captures the depth of poverty in which those below the poverty line are living.

This is disposable household cash income. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits, but does not include in-kind benefits.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

This is disposable household cash income. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits, but does not include in-kind benefits.

column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: 40% of median DHI - poverty gap index
column5:
The poverty gap index calculated at a poverty line of 40% of the median disposable household income. The poverty gap index is a measure that reflects both the depth and prevalence of poverty. It is defined as the mean shortfall of the total population from the poverty line counting the non-poor as having zero shortfall and expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. It is worth unpacking that definition a little. For those below the poverty line, the shortfall corresponds to the amount of money required in order to reach the poverty line. For those at or above the poverty line, the shortfall is counted as zero. The average shortfall is then calculated across the total population – both poor and non-poor – and then expressed as a share of the poverty line. Unlike the more commonly-used metric of the headcount ratio, the poverty gap index is thus sensitive not only to whether a person’s income falls below the poverty line or not, but also by how much – i.e. to the depth of poverty they experience.

This is disposable household cash income. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits, but does not include in-kind benefits.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: $1 a day - total shortfall
column5:
The total shortfall from a poverty line of $1 a day. This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the income of all people in poverty up to the poverty line. However this is not a measure of the actual cost of eliminating poverty, since it does not take into account the costs involved in making the necessary transfers nor any changes in behaviour they would bring about.

This is disposable household cash income. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits, but does not include in-kind benefits.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: $3.65 a day - poverty gap index
column5:
The poverty gap index calculated at a poverty line of $3.65 a day. The poverty gap index is a measure that reflects both the depth and prevalence of poverty. It is defined as the mean shortfall of the total population from the poverty line counting the non-poor as having zero shortfall and expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. It is worth unpacking that definition a little. For those below the poverty line, the shortfall corresponds to the amount of money required in order to reach the poverty line. For those at or above the poverty line, the shortfall is counted as zero. The average shortfall is then calculated across the total population – both poor and non-poor – and then expressed as a share of the poverty line. Unlike the more commonly-used metric of the headcount ratio, the poverty gap index is thus sensitive not only to whether a person’s income falls below the poverty line or not, but also by how much – i.e. to the depth of poverty they experience.

This is disposable household cash income. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits, but does not include in-kind benefits.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: 40% of median DHI - total shortfall
column5:
The total shortfall from a poverty line of 40% of the median disposable household income. This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the income of all people in poverty up to the poverty line. However this is not a measure of the actual cost of eliminating poverty, since it does not take into account the costs involved in making the necessary transfers nor any changes in behaviour they would bring about.

This is disposable household cash income. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits, but does not include in-kind benefits.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: 40% of median DHI - income gap ratio
column5:
The average shortfall from a poverty line of of 40% of the median disposable household income (averaged across the population in poverty) expressed as a share of the poverty line. This metric is sometimes called the "income gap ratio". It captures the depth of poverty in which those below the poverty line are living.

This is disposable household cash income. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits, but does not include in-kind benefits.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

column2: Share below $1 a day
column5:
% of population living in households with income below $1 a day.

This is market income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.

column2: $1 a day - poverty gap index
column5:
The poverty gap index calculated at a poverty line of $1 a day. The poverty gap index is a measure that reflects both the depth and prevalence of poverty. It is defined as the mean shortfall of the total population from the poverty line counting the non-poor as having zero shortfall and expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. It is worth unpacking that definition a little. For those below the poverty line, the shortfall corresponds to the amount of money required in order to reach the poverty line. For those at or above the poverty line, the shortfall is counted as zero. The average shortfall is then calculated across the total population – both poor and non-poor – and then expressed as a share of the poverty line. Unlike the more commonly-used metric of the headcount ratio, the poverty gap index is thus sensitive not only to whether a person’s income falls below the poverty line or not, but also by how much – i.e. to the depth of poverty they experience.

This is market income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

This metric is sometimes called the "income gap ratio". It captures the depth of poverty in which those below the poverty line are living.

This is market income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: 40% of median DHI - poverty gap index
column5:
The poverty gap index calculated at a poverty line of 40% of the median disposable household income. The poverty gap index is a measure that reflects both the depth and prevalence of poverty. It is defined as the mean shortfall of the total population from the poverty line counting the non-poor as having zero shortfall and expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. It is worth unpacking that definition a little. For those below the poverty line, the shortfall corresponds to the amount of money required in order to reach the poverty line. For those at or above the poverty line, the shortfall is counted as zero. The average shortfall is then calculated across the total population – both poor and non-poor – and then expressed as a share of the poverty line. Unlike the more commonly-used metric of the headcount ratio, the poverty gap index is thus sensitive not only to whether a person’s income falls below the poverty line or not, but also by how much – i.e. to the depth of poverty they experience.

This is market income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: $1 a day - total shortfall
column5:
The total shortfall from a poverty line of $1 a day. This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the income of all people in poverty up to the poverty line. However this is not a measure of the actual cost of eliminating poverty, since it does not take into account the costs involved in making the necessary transfers nor any changes in behaviour they would bring about.

This is market income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

Unlike the more commonly-used metric of the headcount ratio, the poverty gap index is thus sensitive not only to whether a person’s income falls below the poverty line or not, but also by how much – i.e. to the depth of poverty they experience.

This is market income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

column2: $10 a day - poverty gap index
column5:
The poverty gap index calculated at a poverty line of $10 a day. The poverty gap index is a measure that reflects both the depth and prevalence of poverty. It is defined as the mean shortfall of the total population from the poverty line counting the non-poor as having zero shortfall and expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. It is worth unpacking that definition a little. For those below the poverty line, the shortfall corresponds to the amount of money required in order to reach the poverty line. The average shortfall is then calculated across the total population – both poor and non-poor – and then expressed as a share of the poverty line. column2: 40% of median DHI - total shortfall
column5:
The total shortfall from a poverty line of 40% of the median disposable household income. This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the income of all people in poverty up to the poverty line. However this is not a measure of the actual cost of eliminating poverty, since it does not take into account the costs involved in making the necessary transfers nor any changes in behaviour they would bring about.

This is market income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

column2: Share below $1 a day
column5:
% of population living in households with consumption below $1 a day.

This is total consumption. Consumption is measured as goods and services purchased by the household, given to the household or self-produced.

Household consumption is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.

This is total consumption. Consumption is measured as goods and services purchased by the household, given to the household or self-produced.

Household consumption is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: $1 a day - poverty gap index
column5:
The poverty gap index calculated at a poverty line of $1 a day. The poverty gap index is a measure that reflects both the depth and prevalence of poverty. It is defined as the mean shortfall of the total population from the poverty line counting the non-poor as having zero shortfall and expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. It is worth unpacking that definition a little. For those below the poverty line, the shortfall corresponds to the amount of money required in order to reach the poverty line. For those at or above the poverty line, the shortfall is counted as zero. The average shortfall is then calculated across the total population – both poor and non-poor – and then expressed as a share of the poverty line. Unlike the more commonly-used metric of the headcount ratio, the poverty gap index is thus sensitive not only to whether a person’s income falls below the poverty line or not, but also by how much – i.e. to the depth of poverty they experience.

This is total consumption. Consumption is measured as goods and services purchased by the household, given to the household or self-produced.

Household consumption is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: 60% of median DHI - income gap ratio
column5:
The average shortfall from a poverty line of of 60% of the median disposable household income (averaged across the population in poverty) expressed as a share of the poverty line. This metric is sometimes called the "income gap ratio". It captures the depth of poverty in which those below the poverty line are living.

This is total consumption. Consumption is measured as goods and services purchased by the household, given to the household or self-produced.

Household consumption is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: 40% of median DHI - poverty gap index
column5:
The poverty gap index calculated at a poverty line of 40% of the median disposable household income. The poverty gap index is a measure that reflects both the depth and prevalence of poverty. It is defined as the mean shortfall of the total population from the poverty line counting the non-poor as having zero shortfall and expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. It is worth unpacking that definition a little. For those below the poverty line, the shortfall corresponds to the amount of money required in order to reach the poverty line. For those at or above the poverty line, the shortfall is counted as zero. The average shortfall is then calculated across the total population – both poor and non-poor – and then expressed as a share of the poverty line. Unlike the more commonly-used metric of the headcount ratio, the poverty gap index is thus sensitive not only to whether a person’s income falls below the poverty line or not, but also by how much – i.e. to the depth of poverty they experience.

This is total consumption. Consumption is measured as goods and services purchased by the household, given to the household or self-produced.

Household consumption is divided by the LIS equivalence scale, which is the square root of the total number of household members to address for economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: $1 a day - total shortfall
column5:
The total shortfall from a poverty line of $1 a day. This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the consumption of all people in poverty up to the poverty line. However this is not a measure of the actual cost of eliminating poverty, since it does not take into account the costs involved in making the necessary transfers nor any changes in behaviour they would bring about.

This is total consumption. Consumption is measured as goods and services purchased by the household, given to the household or self-produced.

Household consumption is divided by the total number of household members.

The average shortfall is then calculated across the total population – both poor and non-poor – and then expressed as a share of the poverty line. Unlike the more commonly-used metric of the headcount ratio, the poverty gap index is thus sensitive not only to whether a person’s income falls below the poverty line or not, but also by how much – i.e. to the depth of poverty they experience.

This is total consumption. Consumption is measured as goods and services purchased by the household, given to the household or self-produced.

Household consumption is divided by the total number of household members.

column2: 40% of median DHI - total shortfall
column5:
The total shortfall from a poverty line of 40% of the median disposable household income. This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the consumption of all people in poverty up to the poverty line. However this is not a measure of the actual cost of eliminating poverty, since it does not take into account the costs involved in making the necessary transfers nor any changes in behaviour they would bring about.

This is total consumption. Consumption is measured as goods and services purchased by the household, given to the household or self-produced.

Household consumption is divided by the total number of household members.

column2: 40% of median DHI - income gap ratio
column5:
The average shortfall from a poverty line of of 40% of the median disposable household income (averaged across the population in poverty) expressed as a share of the poverty line. This metric is sometimes called the "income gap ratio". It captures the depth of poverty in which those below the poverty line are living.
